bibl.idno: The Papers of Henry Rose Carter [manuscript] ; HEALTHSCI MS-10.

bibl.title: Letter from William Y. Hollingsworth to Henry Rose Carter, April 21, 1922

div1.p: Hollingworth answers Carter's questions regarding stegomyia in New Orleans.

div1.head: Letter from William Y. Hollingsworth to Henry Rose Carter, April 21, 1922
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Book Steg Breed.
U. S. Marine Hospital No. 14,
New Orleans, La.
April 21, 1922.
Dr. H. R. Carter,
2121 California St., N.W.,
Washington, D.C.
Dear Doctor:
div1.p:
I am, as you know, not very much of a field man, and have
limited time and knowledge for the kind of observation you wish.
However, I hope to get some information for you from Dr. Metz
of this city, who was very actively interested in yellow fever
work at the time of the epidemic. Also, I have taken up the
matter with Dr. Williams and the two sanitary engineers attached
to the local State Board of Health, and hope I may be able to
glean some worth while information for you.
div1.closer:
Kindest regards to yourself and Miss Laura,
Very truly yours, WY Hollingsworth WYH:en
P. S. --Enclosed is a letter from Dr. Williams which arrived
after the above was written. Sanitary Engineer Allen informs
me that he has seen Steigomya breeding in mud gutters, but they
may have been washed there, and probably were. He also states
that there are practically no mud gutters extant in New Orleans,
nor can he be sure of many in past years. He and Mr. Shaw have
kindly promised to continue their observations. I have not been
able to talk to Dr. Metz, as he has been ill in bed.
Yours,
W.Y.H.
